turn.text: But here... but here, the... the admission is taken as defeating a cause of action, say, in a State court with a jury trial for a malicious act.

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: That is precisely what this Court, in United States v. Smith acknowledged was the result of the Westfall Act, and the intent of Congress.
That even when it cuts off a ordinary, common law tort action against the employee and against the United States, it is still precluded by the Act.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, that's... but there was a judicial determination there of the fact of immunity.
And that isn't so here.

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: No, there was no judicial determination--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The judicial... the determination here is a unilateral determination by the... by the executive.

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --There was no determination in Smith.
There was merely the certification of the Attorney General.
And in Smith this Court indicated that that certification was sufficient to require substitution.
The precise issue here--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But there was no... there was no issue about the certification.
No question was raised about it?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --That's correct.
The precise issue here was not raised there.
But the Court's discussion--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Nobody said that he acted outside the scope of his employment, as I understand it?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --That's correct.
But the Court's discussion certainly indicates an assumption as to how the statutory scheme worked.
That upon certification, the United States was required to be substituted.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you think a certification is reviewable somehow under the Administrative Procedure Act, the final Agency action?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: I... I don't think so, Justice Scalia, because this statute really sort of occupies the field, and sets up its own standards for how the determination is made.
Besides which, I... I view this decision in the light of a discretionary determination by the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What are the standards... you said... you just used the words, set up standards for how the determination is made.
As I understand it, the U.S. Attorneys all over make these certifications or not.
Are there guidelines for them?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: I was unable to find any.
I looked in the U.S. Attorneys manuals and could not find any.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So we don't even know if there's any uniformity in the way these certifications are being handed out, do we?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: That's correct.

But we do know that under the United States' view, scope of employment in this case would be determined under the law of Colombia, which would lead to all sorts of problems as to whether a Federal agent is acting within the scope of his Federal employment.

It would make considerably more sense to have that determination made by the Attorney General or delegated to a U.S. Attorney, to try to determine some sort of uniform Federal standards, rather than have the agent subject to the vagaries of whatever law of whatever country he happens to be in.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is it not conceivable that apart from this procedure, apart from challenging it when... when the... when the certification is made to... to the court that has the tort action, might there not be an action against the... let's suppose an Attorney General who is... or a U.S. Attorney who is making these certifications just randomly, just in order to help both the employee at no expense to the Government, without any investigation whatever... is there a possibility of a separate action under the Administrative Procedure Act to get that... to get that decision overturned?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: Well, I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You'd have a different standard to review.
The court wouldn't determine it de nova.
It would simply determine whether... whether the... the U.S. Attorney's action was arbitrary or capricious.

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --I think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which would be quite different from what... what... what is... what is asked for here.

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --True.
I think as... as an initial matter, there would be potentially Rule 11 sanctions in the court, where the Attorney General or the U.S. Attorney makes this certification.
I mean it is not something that the Attorney General or the U.S. Attorney is likely to take lightly.
Because they do have to go into court.
They do have to say, we've looked into these circumstances.
We are certifying this.
It's a representation to the court that puts the credibility of the United States on the line, and subjects them to potential Rule 11 sanctions.
Now, whether there also be some potential--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: If it's not... if it's not reviewable by the court, how does the court get into it at all for purposes of Rule 11 sanctions?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --Well, in... in many instances, you'll find where a particular side wins the argument, but still could be subject to Rule 11 sanctions for misrepresenting some aspect.
The court, for purposes of substitution, cannot look behind it.

But if the court had reason to believe that in fact no investigation had been... had been conducted or that it was done randomly or arbitrarily, it is a representation to the court, subject to Rule 11.
I'd like to raise a final point about the Article III problems in this case.
Because I think they are quite substantial, if one takes the United States' view of the statute.
I agree absolutely with Justice Scalia's point that when this case reaches Federal court, it is not necessarily a case against the United States.
The question of the proper defendant is precisely the question that the United States says the district court is going to resolve.
And until that question is resolved, the identity of the defendant is not determined.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought the United States "shall be substituted"... so why isn't it a case against the United States?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: It does say, "shall be substituted", but if it's subject to review by the district court, then--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I didn't understand you either.
You mean on the basis of the other side's case--

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --You don't know it's the United States when you get to court?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But on the basis of your case, you do know?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: You do know.
It is a suit against the United States, and therefore there is no jurisdictional problem, because it's a suit against the United States that's clearly covered by Article III.
But on the Solicitor General's view, if the defendant is properly identified as the employee because he was acting outside of the scope of employment, then there is no Federal question--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why is it any different from pendant jurisdiction?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --Pendant jurisdiction involves two claims generally.
One--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but here they came into Federal court on a good basis.
There's a suit.
It's determined that, hey, this is a simple assault and battery.
The attorney... it's not in the scope of employment at all.
The Federal forum remains.
It came in on a good basis.
Why can't it remain pendant, just like a State pendant claim?

turn.speaker: michael_k_kellogg
turn.label: Mr. Michael K. Kellogg
turn.text: --Because I don't think it makes sense to say it came in on a good basis if it's the district court that makes the determination, not the Attorney General.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Kellogg.
The case is submitted.
